Description.Name: Uninvited Truths
Description.Details: You return to your quarters late, expecting a few system reports and a half-charged sleep cycle. Instead, your personal datapad is flashing. A new message, with the Subject FOR YOUR EYES ONLY. No senders listed. No traceable headers. Just a single embedded file. Against your better judgment, you open it. It’s text-only. No signature. No voice. But you recognize the cadence instantly—and the symbol at the bottom removes all doubt: the crest of the [[DM.Factions[faction_MinnesotaTribe],Minnesota Tribe]]. “You didn’t believe me when I told you what the Ghost Bears are willing to hide. But now you’ve seen it firsthand. Your handler has admitted to violating her own Clan’s command structure. She has endangered your outfit, your reputation, and your future for her own crusade. And she never told you why. I would like to speak again. This time, I will bring you more of the truth. Things Arelle will never tell you. Speak to no one before deciding. This offer is only for you.” You read it twice. Then a third time. She knows. About the call with Arelle. The 4 billion. The confession. You haven’t spoken to anyone outside the crew. That message was buried in encrypted transmission layers. And yet... Mizuki knows. You consider your options.

Description.Name: Speak to her alone
Description.Details: You’ll take the call yourself. No crew. No backup. If she’s telling the truth—or manipulating it—you’ll hear her out with clear eyes. You prepare a private connection protocol, isolated from the Argo’s comm grid. Whatever this is, you’ll face it alone.

Description.Name: Speak to her with the crew
Speak to her with the crew
Description.Details:
<color=#BFBFBF>If this is another trap, you won’t walk into it alone. The crew deserves to hear what’s being said—whatever it is.

 You summon Darius, Farah, Sumire, and Yang to the conference room. If Mizuki wants to speak, she’ll speak to all of you.</color>

Description.Name: Ignore the message
Description.Details:
<color=#BFBFBF>No more games. You made your choice. You won’t let the Tribe worm their way back in through words.

You delete the message and wipe the memory sector clean. Some truths—whatever they are—aren’t worth the risk.</color>
